newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - Dlr/yen vols off highs, but stay well bid.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - Dlr/yen vols off highs, but stay well bid.

text.p: Implied volatilities for dollar/yen options firmed as the dollar extended gains, although the shorter maturities were recoiling from early highs by U.S. midsession as spot pulled back, dealers said.
The longer dates were again the epicenter of frantic trading as the market braced for continued strength in the dollar, they added.

"We've broken through key technical levels, and also with the short option positions that are there (in the higher strike prices), we're seeing a bit of a short squeeze," said Soma Rao, options sales manager at Smith Barney.
He noted that the dollar crossed above its still-upsloping 200-day moving average on Tuesday near 118 yen, convincing many traders that its long-term uptrend was intact.

Traders said big hedge fund purchases recently of one-year yen puts with strike prices around 125 yen were having a lingering effect on the market as many interbank dealers had become short in longer-dated options.

"It's been busy in the back-date yen," said an interbank broker in New York. "With spot creeping up here toward 119 (yen), a lot of people, I think, were short and they're sort of scrambling to buy one-year at-the-money."
He said sizeable trades were done in one-year dollar/yen at 12.0 to 12.05 percent implied volatility. The one-year had been quoted at 11.8/12.0 percent late on Tuesday and 11.0/11.3 last Friday.
Front-end volatilities jumped earlier as spot probed the 119-yen area, the highest levels since the spectacular May-June slide toward 110 yen, but quickly retraced.
Dealers who bought the back end were seen selling the front end to trim time decay in their postions.
One-month stood at 11.3/11.6 percent after rising toward 12 percent, compared with 11.4/11.7 late on Tuesday.
Still, growing perception that the dollar would eventually test 120 yen and higher kept risk reversals, the put/call pricing differential, steadily in favor of yen puts.
One-month dollar/yen risk reversal stood at 0.3/0.6 percent skewed for yen puts, little changed on the day.
A U.S. bank trader said mark/yen risk reversals were also beginning to show weakness in the yen as spot had bounced off last week's two-year lows below 63 yen toward the mid-64s.
"Mark/yen risk reversals have turned around in the short dates," he said, adding that the yen calls were still favored two-month. "It used to be pretty solidly for yen calls."
Dollar/mark volatilities were mixed as spot consolidated in the 1.8300-1.8450 mark range.
"The fronts are coming in with spot settling down, but the backs are still bid," the bank trader said. "I think that's kind of been the story throughout (the forex market)."
He added that shorter-dated sterling volatilities had softened as the sterling's steep downturn that started late last week appeared pausing.
One-month cable and sterling/mark volatilities were assessed at 9.3/9.5 and 10.8/11.1 percent respectively against 9.5/9.9 and 11.2/11.5 late on Tuesday.
-- Shin Kishima/Chicago Derivatives Desk ((312-408-8750))
